newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico '97 budget seeks $5 bln net borrowing limit.
newsitem.headline: Mexico '97 budget seeks $5 bln net borrowing limit.

text.p: The Mexican government will seek a $5.0 billion limit on net foreign borrowing in 1997, according to its budget proposal delivered to Congress on Thursday.
"With relation to external debt, the initiative proposes a limit to net external public sector debt in the national currency equal to $5.0 billion (U.S.)," the budget said.

The increase in public debt will allow Mexican development banks to give a boost to exporters and allow investment spending by the National Electricity Commission and Petroleos Mexicanos to increase, the budget said.

"The federal government resorts to external debt mainly with the object of refinancing existing debts in better conditions," the budget said. "As a consequence the external debt of the federal government will not vary significantly with respect to the end of 1996."
With respect to the internal debt, the public sector deficit will rise to 15.89 billion pesos or 0.5 percent of gross domestic product.
The deficit will reflect a surplus of 18.348 billion pesos and a federal government deficit of 34.238 billion pesos, the government said.
"With these numbers, we are looking for ... a federal government net internal debt of 34.0 billion pesos," the budget proposal said.
